BC-SCI-TESTES-CANCER-NYT 
FROM A PEA-SIZED LUMP, YEARS OF UNCERTAINTY 

   (The Science Times)  
Sandeep Jauhar is a resident in internal medicine at New York
Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Center. 
 By SANDEEP JAUHAR, M.D.    
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   One evening last summer, Jonah M. came to see me at my clinic.
Because he had a walk-in appointment, I figured he had a minor
problem _ maybe a sore throat, a sprained ankle _ that I could help
him with right away. When he sat in my examination room, his face
was flushed. ``I have a lump on my testicle,'' he announced.

   He was 29, handsome, with unruly brown hair, hazel eyes and a
nervous earnestness that was instantly likable. He had a kind of
California surfer drawl that bespoke nonchalance, but his darting
glances and stammer betrayed his anxiety. The lump was about the
size of a pea, he said. It didn't hurt. He had noticed it only the
night before.

   I was immediately concerned. A painless testicular mass, if
indeed it arises from the testicle, is almost always cancer. (A
scrotal mass can turn out to be a varicocele, or benign dilated
veins.) Of course, testicular cancer isn't always a painless
testicular mass. Sometimes it is a painful lump or tender swelling.
Often it is confused with epididymitis, an inflammation of the
tubules that ferry sperm out of the testis, or orchitis, which is
the generalized inflammation of the testes, usually from an
infection.

   While talking with Jonah, I remembered another patient: His
disease had been misdiagnosed for months as epididymitis, before an
ultrasound found cancer. By then, it had spread to his brain and
lungs.

   For Jonah, an exam turned up nothing out of the ordinary other
than the lump, which was round, rubbery and about half an inch in
diameter. Though I had almost no experience with testicular cancer,
I knew this was serious.

   ``What do you think?'' Jonah asked.

   I wasn't sure what to say. ``I'm not sure,'' I replied. ``It may
be nothing. Let me consult with another doctor.''

   As a medical resident, I went to my supervisor. Concerned, she
came with me to examine it. Later, in her office, we discussed what
to do. ``It's probably cancer,'' she said.``He needs an ultrasound
to confirm it.'' Though excited by my discovery, I was saddened by
the burden I was about to lay on Jonah. ``Good pickup,'' she said,
aware of my feelings. ``You caught it early. He can probably be
cured.''

   When I got back to my exam room 15 minutes later, Jonah was even
more on edge. ``What do I have?'' he asked. I decided not to burden
him unnecessarily with unconfirmed suspicions. ``I don't know,'' I
replied. ``We need more information. Can you come in tomorrow for
an ultrasound?'' A wave of alarm washed over him. ``Do I have
cancer?'' he whispered.

   ``I just don't know at this point,'' I said. ``We need more
information.''

   Testicular cancer is the most common solid tumor in men 15 to
34. The incidence has been rising worldwide, and in the United
States 7,000 to 8,000 cases are diagnosed every year. The cause is
unknown, though men with a history of viral infections or an
undescended testicle seem more at risk.

   Like most cancers, it used to be a death sentence; today, with
advances in chemotherapy, it has a cure rate of 90 percent. Even
patients whose cancer has metastasized can usually be cured. (Just
ask Lance Armstrong, the cyclist who won the Tour de France three
years after debilitating chemotherapy for metastatic testicular
cancer.) Still, it's a frightening diagnosis, not just because it's
cancer, but because the primary treatment is one of the scariest
things a man can envision: removal of a testicle.

   Jonah had his ultrasound the next morning. By 5, the urology
resident paged me. ``It's cancer,'' he said. The test showed a
round, well-defined mass, about five-eighths of an inch in
diameter, on top of the right testicle. ``Have you told him?'' I
asked. ``I'm about to,'' he replied.

   Jonah later told me how he got the bad news. ``The resident just
walked right in with his team and told me,'' he said. ``He was very
take-charge and matter of fact. His attitude was, ``This is what
you have, and this is what we need to do about it.''

   ``But it was sort of like _ boom! _ I wasn't expecting it. The
scariest thing is how you can be just fine one minute, and the next
have someone tell you you have cancer and need to have your
testicle removed.''

   Three days later, Jonah had an orchiectomy, the removal of a
testicle. He was out of the hospital that day, and though morphine
and codeine relieved the pain, he said later that there was a far
more painful reality: ``That my body was not going to be the
same.''

   His biggest fear after surgery was sexual inadequacy. Because an
orchiectomy often results in a drop in serum testosterone, he was
warned that he might need hormone replacement. He never did, and
after a few weeks, with the occasional help of Viagra, he resumed
normal sexual relations with his girlfriend.

   After the operation, Jonah consulted a cancer specialist, who
told him that his kind of testicular cancer had about a 30 percent
chance of recurrence and he had two options: dissection of the
lymph nodes in his groin and abdomen for evidence of residual
disease, or ``watchful waiting,'' in which he would have blood
tests and X-rays every month, as well as CAT scans every three
months. He waited, and soon it will be a year since Jonah walked
into the clinic. So far, so good.

   ``Sometimes, late at night, I lie awake thinking. Like, if I
don't move around, don't stir, it won't emerge again. Like if I
move around too much, I might awaken it. Like it's this beast,'' he
said.

   A beast, I agreed: asleep and scary, but one that can be killed.
